name: Middle of the Linked List

similar_questions.title: Delete the Middle Node of a Linked List
Maximum Twin Sum of a Linked List

title: Middle of the Linked List
content:
Given the head of a singly linked list, return the middle node of the linked list.

If there are two middle nodes, return the second middle node.

 

Example 1:

Input: head = [1,2,3,4,5]
Output: [3,4,5]
Explanation: The middle node of the list is node 3.

Example 2:

Input: head = [1,2,3,4,5,6]
Output: [4,5,6]
Explanation: Since the list has two middle nodes with values 3 and 4, we return the second one.

 

Constraints:

  • The number of nodes in the list is in the range [1, 100].
  • 1 <= Node.val <= 100

discussion_posts.name: KovDimaY
discussion_posts.content: People who refers to their \'\'perfomance\'\' reports, keep in mind the fact that two consecutive submissions of mine with NO changes in the code just gave me report of \'\'Beats 95.40%\'\' and the next one \'\'Beats 6.41%\'\'. And this happens with all the challenges I tried solving so far on this platform. Do not take it so serious, is just a random number generator \uD83D\uDE09

discussion_posts.name: zunairarif89
discussion_posts.content: Use two pointer approach slow and fast. Slow takes one step and fast takes two steps. for example if a fast person cover 10km then slow person covers its half of the distance. So when the fast pointer reaches to the last node then slow pointer reaches to the middle of the linked list. and at last return slow that is the middle node. That\'s All. Easy Peasy! Happy Coding

discussion_posts.name: halyna-dev
discussion_posts.content: I don\'t understand why output should be an array instead of middle value in linked list. I watched video explanation from \'Explore - LeetCode\' course and there are other output.\n[link to course](https://leetcode.com/explore/learn/card/the-leetcode-beginners-guide/692/challenge-problems/4426/)

discussion_posts.name: hraynaud
discussion_posts.content: It looks like this question is broken. The description doesn\'t match the desired output. The question and visual example clearly state that only one node is desired but the expected result in the test cases is and array of nodes.

discussion_posts.name: Oranzh
discussion_posts.content: Use two pointers, one slow pointer and one fast pointer.\nThe slow pointer moves one step at a time while the fast pointer moves two steps at a time.\nBy the time the fast pointer reaches the end of the linked list, the slow pointer will be at the middle node

discussion_posts.name: SyKing
discussion_posts.content: why cant i use \'slice\' in js?\n

discussion_posts.name: purpleladydragons
discussion_posts.content: Is two pointers actually any better than keeping count of the length and iterating again to midway? You still end up doing the same number of operations
